discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I believe privacy laws (GDPR for instance) get preference over data subject consent.

Best Answer is B. Allowing data transfer between regions often hinges on the presence of a legal basis, and the public interest is a strong justification recognized under many data protection regulations (such as GDPR). This basis allows organizations to transfer data when it serves a broader public interest, such as in matters of health, safety, or humanitarian reasons.

comments.content: However Answer A sounds much more reasonable and accurate. In many data privacy regulations, such as the GDPR, one of the lawful bases for transferring personal data across regions is when it is necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is a party, or for taking steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract. This is often considered an implicit form of consent because the data transfer is essential to fulfill a contract or service that the data subject expects.

choices.B: There is a legal basis of public interest.
choices.A: Data subjects give implicit consent for a contract or claim.
choices.D: There are legitimate interests that override data subject rights.
choices.C: Data transfer concerns a limited number of data subjects.
